Conant, R. and J. T. Collins. 1991. A field guide to reptiles and amphibians:eastern and central North America. Third edition. Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, Massachusetts. 450 pp.
NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.

Adalsteinsson, S. A., W. R. Branch, S. Trape, L. J. Vitt, and S. B. Hedges. 2009. Molecular phylogeny, classification, and biogeography of snakes of the family Leptotyphlopidae (Reptilia, Squamata). Zootaxa 2244:1-50.
Ernst, C. H., and E. M. Ernst. 2003. Snakes of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Books, Washington, D.C.
Degenhardt, W., Painter, C., and A. Price.  1996. Amphibians and reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 429 pages.
habitat_description:
*The leptotyphlopid species of North America (dissecta, dulcis, humilis) were removed from the genus Leptotyphlops and assigned to the genus Rena after Adalsteinsson et al. 2009 examined DNA sequences of the family Leptotyphlopidae.

This species occurs from southeastern Colorado, southwestern Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, northern and western Texas, and southeastern Arizona. In Mexico, this species is found in northern Chihuahua and Coahuila (Collins 1993, Degenhardt et al. 1996, Werler and Dixon 2000). The habitat of this fossorial snake includes rocky and sandy deserts, prairies, prairie canyons, and pinion/juniper, juniper/oak woodlands (Degenhardt et al. 1996, Ernst and Ernst 2003).

SW-	Pinyon/juniper and juniper/oak woodland (Degenhardt et al. 1996)
